courses.LIT 1 — Literary Interpretation:
Course: LIT 1 — Literary Interpretation
Credits: 5
Description: Close reading and analysis of literary texts, including representative examples of several different genres and periods. An introduction to practical criticism required of all literature majors; should be completed prior to upper-division work in literature.
Requirements: Requirements Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Enrollment is restricted to first-year students and sophomores, or literature and proposed literature majors and literature minors.
courses.LIT 42D — Student Directed Seminar: Crit:
Course: LIT 42D — Student Directed Seminar: Critical Engagement with Capitalism Through Literature and Media
Credits: 5
Description: Familiarizes students with key topics in socioeconomic and societal critique of capitalism through a variety of readings. By the end of the course, students will engage with important concepts through a variety of literature and media in order to provide a multifaceted introduction to literary modes of social criticism and analysis.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 60A — The Graphic Novel: Memoirs:
Course: LIT 60A — The Graphic Novel: Memoirs
Credits: 5
Description: Survey of graphic novel memoirs. Class focuses on how the pairing of text and images in sequential art offers a form of disclosure for conveying experiences of personal identity, self-invention, and environmental degradation. Special attention is given to the work of non-binary, queer, and feminist perspectives. Students write weekly creative-critical responses and a final creative-critical paper.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61C — Devils, Dervishes, and Bawdy T:
Course: LIT 61C — Devils, Dervishes, and Bawdy Tales from Baghdad to Canterbury: The Story within the Story
Credits: 5
Description: A story within a story, the frame tale is a playful and enduring literary genre. Focuses on frame tales of the global middle ages, tracing their movement from the Indian subcontinent to the British Isles. Readings include selections from Fables of Bidpai, The Arabian Nights, Libro de Buen Amor, and The Canterbury Tales. (Formerly The Frame Tale.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61F — Introduction to Reading Fictio:
Course: LIT 61F — Introduction to Reading Fiction
Credits: 5
Description: Close reading of short stories and some novels with the aim of developing critical methods for the analysis and interpretation of prose fiction. Topics include character, plot, narrative structure, and the poetics of prose. The course topic changes; please see the Class Search for the current topic.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.LIT 61H — Reading the Movies:
Course: LIT 61H — Reading the Movies
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces techniques for the close reading of film (shot-by-shot analysis, etc.), with particular attention to what makes film different from other media. Films studied will cohere around a specific theme, geography, or genre, like film noir. (Formerly Introduction to Film Analysis.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61J — Introduction to Jewish Literat:
Course: LIT 61J — Introduction to Jewish Literature and Culture
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys 3,000 years of Jewish literature and culture. Themes include origins of the Jews in the ancient world; formation and persistence of the Jewish diaspora; coherence and diversity of Jewish experience; Jewish narrative and textual traditions; interaction between Jews and other cultures; tensions between tradition and modernity.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61K — Introduction to the Fairy Tale:
Course: LIT 61K — Introduction to the Fairy Tale
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the fairy tale as a genre, including historical, cultural, and political contexts; relation to identity, performance, transnationalism; contemporary transformations of tales and their expression in other media (e.g., film, art, theater); and current scholarship.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61L — True Stories: Memoir:
Course: LIT 61L — True Stories: Memoir
Credits: 5
Description: Historical overview of the genre from Augustine to contemporary experiments in memoir. Student write weekly creative-critical responses and a final creative-critical paper.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61M — Approaches to Classical Myth:
Course: LIT 61M — Approaches to Classical Myth
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to Greek myths, including selected ancient texts and visual artifacts, historical and cultural context of their creation and reception, modern theoretical approaches such as structuralism and psychoanalysis, and interpretations in various media.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61N — Introduction to Children's Lit:
Course: LIT 61N — Introduction to Children's Literature
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to children's literature as a literary genre, including historical, cultural, and political considerations of the genre's relationship to gender, race, sexuality, nationalism, colonialism, and popular culture through primary texts, secondary criticism, and other media (e.g., film, illustration, comics).
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61P — Introduction to Reading Poetry:
Course: LIT 61P — Introduction to Reading Poetry
Credits: 5
Description: An introduction to selected modes and forms of poetry with an emphasis on close textual analysis. Examples will be taken from different historical periods and poetic traditions. Course topic changes; please see the Class Search for the current topic.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61R — Race in Literature:
Course: LIT 61R — Race in Literature
Credits: 5
Description: An investigation into the various uses and abuses of race in literature. Course topic changes; see the Class Search for current topic.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61S — Sacred Texts:
Course: LIT 61S — Sacred Texts
Credits: 5
Description: Studies religious texts held sacred by different cultures and communities around the world, concentrating primarily on their literary dimensions. Course topic changes; please see the Class Search for current topic.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61T — Travel Narratives:
Course: LIT 61T — Travel Narratives
Credits: 5
Description: Travel narratives may be of many types: odysseys of self-discovery, adventures in nature, or journeys to exotic lands off the beaten track. This course examines travelers' accounts drawn from periods ranging from the Middle Ages to the contemporary.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61U — Introduction to Speculative Fi:
Course: LIT 61U — Introduction to Speculative Fiction
Credits: 5
Description: Examines speculative and science fiction (SF) texts to develop critical methods for the analysis and interpretation of SF as a critique of science, technology, and culture. Themes include encounters across species; novelty and change; expanded concepts of life; and the role of technology in human development.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61W — Writing and Research Methods:
Course: LIT 61W — Writing and Research Methods
Credits: 5
Description: Intensive training in the practice of literary analysis and the writing of polished research papers. Topics include manuscript sources, variant editions, reading techniques, publication technologies, web research. Workshop format. Strongly recommended for majors and/or transfer students who have completed LIT 1 or its equivalent.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61X — Tragedy: Learning Through Suff:
Course: LIT 61X — Tragedy: Learning Through Suffering
Credits: 5
Description: Reading representative Greek tragedies with attention to history, form, and content. Course examines how Greek tragedy responds to the fact of human mortality, i.e., to the myriad and culturally specific ways in which characters in tragedy accept, evade, or deny death.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61Y — Arthurian Romance:
Course: LIT 61Y — Arthurian Romance
Credits: 5
Description: Reading of selected Arthurian romances in verse and prose from the French, Welsh, and English traditions.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 61Z — Introduccion a generos literar:
Course: LIT 61Z — Introduccion a generos literarios de Espana y America Latina
Credits: 5
Description: Speaking, reading, and writing proficiency in Spanish required. The study of poetry, drama, and prose in Spain and Latin America.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80B — Monsters and Literature:
Course: LIT 80B — Monsters and Literature
Credits: 5
Description: Every age has the monsters it needs. From medieval marvels to GMO chimeras, monsters serve as figures of a culture's deepest fears, anxieties, and hidden desires. This course takes a multidisciplinary, transhistorical approach to the problems and promises of monsters, and introduces monster theory.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80D — Literary Traditions of India:
Course: LIT 80D — Literary Traditions of India
Credits: 5
Description: Introduces the fundamental questions of interpretation and cultural analysis through engagement with varying literary and cultural traditions of the Indian subcontinent since antiquity. Emphasis is on language, communicative media, literary form, memory, transmission, interpretive approaches, and translation. The course topics change; please see the Class Search for the current topic.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.LIT 80E — Animals and Literature:
Course: LIT 80E — Animals and Literature
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the copresence in literary works (fiction and non-fiction prose and poetry) of nonhuman and human animals from antiquity to the present across a variety of cultures.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80H — The Politics of Fashion:
Course: LIT 80H — The Politics of Fashion
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys the politics of fashion, focusing on how style has shaped ideology, culture, power, revolution, resistance, and a variety of identities, including nation, race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, and class.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80I — Topics in American Culture:
Course: LIT 80I — Topics in American Culture
Credits: 5
Description: A history of one or more cultural genres in written, visual, and/or musical forms. Course topic changes; please see the Class Search for the current topic.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.LIT 80K — Topics in Medical Humanities:
Course: LIT 80K — Topics in Medical Humanities
Credits: 5
Description: Medical Humanities designate an interdisciplinary field of humanities (literature, philosophy, ethics, history, and religion) concerned with application to medical education and practice. The humanities provide insight into the human condition, suffering, personhood, and our responsibility to each other; and offer a historical perspective on medical practice.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80L — The Holocaust: The Destruction:
Course: LIT 80L — The Holocaust: The Destruction of European Jewry
Credits: 5
Description: Focus is on the destruction of the Jews of Europe by Nazi Germany. Issues are historically grounded, and include works of literature, social sciences, philosophy, and film.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80M — China in the Post-Reform Perio:
Course: LIT 80M — China in the Post-Reform Period
Credits: 5
Description: Speaking, reading, and writing proficiency in Mandarin Chinese required. Lectures, discussions, writing assignments, and all readings in Chinese. Topics include labor, gender, generational divisions, family, urban life, social media, nationalism.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80N — Latino Expressions in the U.S:
Course: LIT 80N — Latino Expressions in the U.S
Credits: 5
Description: An introduction to Latino literature and culture in the U.S. A study of the creative expressions of Chicanos/as, Nuyoricans, Cuban Americans, and other Latin Americans in the U.S.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80O — Love, Anarchy, Revolution:
Course: LIT 80O — Love, Anarchy, Revolution
Credits: 5
Description: Considers love, anarchy, and revolution as three modes of liberation. Concentrating on the contemporary period, with explorations of philosophy, literature, film, popular culture, political movements and manifestos, and personal or collective experience, this course considers these variant, but overlapping, scenes of the dialectics of liberation.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80P — Topics in Latin American Cultu:
Course: LIT 80P — Topics in Latin American Culture
Credits: 5
Description: Through films, literary texts, historical, sociological, and anthropological writings, explores topics pertaining to Latin American culture and society. Course topic changes; please see the Schedule of Classes for current topic.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.LIT 80Q — Jane the Virgin: Latinx Reader:
Course: LIT 80Q — Jane the Virgin: Latinx Readers and (Latin) American Literature
Credits: 5
Description: What does a telenovela spoof about a virgin Latinx mother and aspiring romance novelist have to do with literature? Course explores Jane the Virgin as a commentary on the tastes, identities, and politics of 21st-century Latinx readers and writers.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80T — Practical Magic:
Course: LIT 80T — Practical Magic
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the early history of written magic in Africa, Europe, and Asia, as well as the ramifications of that history for the shape of the modern world. Students learn how to cast ancient spells efficaciously and compose spells of their own. (Formerly Literature and Magic.)
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80U — Introduction to Contemplative:
Course: LIT 80U — Introduction to Contemplative Reading
Credits: 5
Description: Combines contemplative practice, including meditative practice, with close reading of literary works to provide students with a more precise ability to interpret and respond to texts, both literary and non-literary. Works include poetry, imaginative prose, and essays.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80V — Literature and History:
Course: LIT 80V — Literature and History
Credits: 5
Description: Examines literature's relationship to the past and to the experience of history. Course topic changes; please see the Class Search for current topic.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80W — Captive Minds: The Literature:
Course: LIT 80W — Captive Minds: The Literature of Pre-modern Slavery
Credits: 5
Description: Examines the literary production of slave societies by looking at the literatures of several pre-modern slave societies; also develops a cultural-historical narrative that explains the origins of genocidal forms of plantation slavery in the Americas by tracing their origins back to Greece and Rome.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 80X — Global Narratives:
Course: LIT 80X — Global Narratives

Course: LIT 81A — Homer's Odyssey

An epic tale of a man who abandons his family to fight in the Trojan War, then returns two decades later, the Odyssey was a profound influence on the culture of ancient Greece and Rome, and continues to shape our self-understanding today.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 81B — Literature and Photography:
Course: LIT 81B — Literature and Photography
Credits: 5
Description: Explores the close relationship between photography and literature, from the origins of photography to 19th-century realism and the contemporary photographic novel, interpreting photographs and literature to study how these fields influence each other and how their forms of representation relate.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 81C — The Novels of Toni Morrison:
Course: LIT 81C — The Novels of Toni Morrison
Credits: 5
Description: Examines novels by Toni Morrison, including The Bluest Eye, Song of Solomon, Sula, and Jazz, as sites of discontent and transformation, while also considering literary techniques such as form, voice, metaphor, and narrative structure. Includes discussion of Morrison's ideas about the intersection of race and sexuality, blackness as a shifting signifier, the role of the artist in society, and uses of literature for re-imagining the relationships between history, culture, and individuality.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 81D — The Prophet and the Qurâan:
Course: LIT 81D — The Prophet and the Qurâan
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to the life of the Prophet Muhammad as a literary text and as a primary hermeneutic framework for understanding the Qur'an, including its relationship to a deep narrative prophetic tradition shared with other Abrahamic traditions.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 81E — Social Media and Society:
Course: LIT 81E — Social Media and Society
Credits: 5
Description: Introduction to social media's evolving impact on society. How are social media changing communication, politics, identity, privacy, and what we believe? Materials include critical texts and real-world case studies, as well as films and short fiction.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 81F — Ghosts of Slavery, 1960-80s/20:
Course: LIT 81F — Ghosts of Slavery, 1960-80s/2000-20s
Credits: 5
Description: Why does the history of slavery reappear at certain moments in literary and popular culture? Course focuses on the 1960s and the 2000s, when slavery was frequently featured in popular and academic history, fiction, film, and television, in both imaginative and documentary forms.
Requirements: American History and Institutions Yes
courses.LIT 81G — The Good Life:
Course: LIT 81G — The Good Life
Credits: 5
Description: Do current social, political, and psychological conditions make it more difficult to live a good life? Drawing on the broad tradition of critical theory and utopian imaginings, the course aims to give practical and theoretical guidance toward achieving a good life.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 81H — Literature and Pandemic: The W:
Course: LIT 81H — Literature and Pandemic: The World at the End of the World
Credits: 5
Description: Surveys some of the most famous accounts and representations of historical and fictional pandemics in the history of literature, mostly from the Western tradition. Students read excerpts from works by Thucydides, Lucretius, Boccaccio, Manzoni, Poe, Camus, London, and Elkhadem. Conversation centers on the question of how Western literature have attempted to both document and investigate the destruction of human society, but also to recreate it.
Requirements: Repeatable for credit Yes
courses.LIT 81I — Engineering California:
Course: LIT 81I — Engineering California
Credits: 5
Description: Online course using literary and artistic texts to investigate the history and engineering of California, and to imagine a virtual, material, and cultural infrastructure for California's future. Course begins and ends with the Internet, and includes topics such as cyberspace, the Gold Rush, Spanish/Mexican missions, wartime development, and early cybernetics.
Requirements: No additional requirements listed.
courses.LIT 81J — The 1001 Nights:
